questions.stem: A therapist is treating a client with recurrent depression who has had four previous episodes. The client is currently in remission but the therapist wants to reduce the risk of relapse. Which intervention has the STRONGEST evidence for this specific indication?

options.text: Behavioral Activation (BA) targeting increased positive reinforcement and activity scheduling
Mindfulness-Based Cognitive Therapy (MBCT) to develop decentering skills and metacognitive awareness
Interpersonal Therapy (IPT) focused on the role transition associated with recovery
Schema Therapy targeting early maladaptive schemas that predispose to depression

questions.explanation: MBCT (Segal, Williams, & Teasdale) is specifically designed as a relapse prevention intervention for individuals with three or more previous depressive episodes who are currently in remission. It reduces relapse rates by approximately 50% compared to treatment as usual. MBCT teaches decentering -- the ability to observe thoughts as mental events rather than reality -- to prevent the 'depressive interlock' where minor mood fluctuations trigger ruminative cascades. BA and IPT are treatments for acute depression, not specifically for relapse prevention in remitted patients.

questions.stem: In Dialectical Behavior Therapy (DBT), a client reports self-harming during the past week and also missing two skills group sessions. According to the DBT treatment target hierarchy, which issue should the individual therapist address FIRST?

options.text: Skills group attendance, as therapy-interfering behaviors take priority in DBT
The self-harm, as life-threatening behaviors are the highest priority target
Both should be addressed simultaneously using a behavioral chain analysis
The therapist should address whichever issue the client places on the session agenda

questions.explanation: DBT follows a strict treatment target hierarchy in individual therapy: (1) life-threatening behaviors (including self-harm and suicidal behavior) are always addressed first, (2) therapy-interfering behaviors (including missing sessions), (3) quality-of-life-interfering behaviors, and (4) skills acquisition. The self-harm must be addressed before the missed sessions, even though both are important targets. Diary cards are reviewed at the start of each session to identify which targets to address according to this hierarchy.

questions.stem: A depressed client states, 'I failed my exam, so I'm a complete failure at everything.' According to Beck's cognitive model, this automatic thought BEST illustrates which cognitive distortion?

options.text: Personalization -- attributing external events to oneself without basis
Mental filter -- selectively attending to a single negative detail
Overgeneralization -- viewing a single negative event as a never-ending pattern of defeat
Magnification -- exaggerating the importance of a negative event

questions.explanation: Overgeneralization involves viewing a single negative event as a never-ending pattern. The client takes one exam failure and concludes they are 'a complete failure at everything,' extending one specific failure to a global, pervasive pattern. Personalization would involve taking responsibility for external events (e.g., 'The team lost because of me'). Mental filter would focus selectively on the failure while ignoring successes. Magnification would exaggerate the exam failure's significance without generalizing to all domains.

questions.stem: In Interpersonal Therapy (IPT) for depression, the therapist assigns the client the 'sick role' early in treatment. What is the PRIMARY purpose of this intervention?

options.text: To justify the client's withdrawal from social responsibilities until depression remits
To legitimize the depression as an illness, reduce guilt and self-blame, and mobilize the client for treatment
To provide a diagnostic label that facilitates insurance reimbursement for therapy
To establish a power differential where the therapist is the expert directing the client's recovery

questions.explanation: In IPT, the 'sick role' is assigned early in treatment to acknowledge that the client has a legitimate illness (depression) that is not their fault. This serves to reduce guilt and self-blame, normalize difficulties, and mobilize the client to work toward recovery as they would with any medical illness. It is one of IPT's most distinctive features. It does NOT excuse the client from all responsibilities or create a power differential; rather, it reframes depression as a treatable condition.

questions.stem: Behavioral Activation (BA) for depression emerged from a landmark component analysis study demonstrating that:

options.text: The cognitive component of CBT was more effective than the behavioral component alone
The behavioral component of CBT was as effective as the full cognitive-behavioral package
Combined CBT plus medication was necessary for any meaningful improvement in severe depression
Interpersonal interventions were more effective than behavioral interventions for chronic depression

questions.explanation: Behavioral Activation (Jacobson et al., 1996) emerged from a component analysis showing that the behavioral component of CBT was as effective as the full cognitive-behavioral package for depression. This was replicated in the Dimidjian et al. (2006) trial, which showed BA was equally effective as full CBT -- even for severe depression, where BA performed as well as antidepressant medication. BA is based on the theory that depression results from decreased response-contingent positive reinforcement.

questions.stem: Select ALL accurate descriptions of the four modes of standard DBT treatment:

options.text: Individual therapy (weekly, 1 hour) addresses the treatment target hierarchy using chain analysis
Skills training group (weekly, 2.5 hours) is a structured psychoeducational format teaching four modules
Phone coaching provides brief between-session support to help generalize skills to everyday crises
Therapist consultation team meets weekly to support therapist motivation and prevent burnout
Process-oriented group therapy provides emotional support and interpersonal feedback among BPD clients

questions.explanation: Standard DBT has four modes: (1) individual therapy (weekly, 1 hour) using the treatment hierarchy and chain analysis; (2) skills training group (weekly, 2.5 hours) -- a structured psychoeducational format teaching mindfulness, distress tolerance, emotion regulation, and interpersonal effectiveness; (3) phone coaching (as needed) for brief crisis support and skills generalization; and (4) therapist consultation team (weekly) for therapist support and preventing burnout. The skills group is explicitly NOT process-oriented group therapy.

questions.stem: Select ALL four interpersonal problem areas that are the focus of treatment in Interpersonal Therapy (IPT):

options.text: Grief (complicated bereavement or unresolved loss)
Role disputes (conflicts with significant others about expectations)
Cognitive distortions (systematic errors in thinking that maintain depression)
Role transitions (life changes such as retirement, divorce, or new parenthood)
Interpersonal deficits (chronic social isolation or poor social skills)

questions.explanation: IPT (Klerman et al., 1984) focuses on four interpersonal problem areas: grief, role disputes, role transitions, and interpersonal deficits. IPT does NOT directly address cognitive distortions -- that is a CBT technique. IPT works on the interpersonal context that triggers and maintains depression, using communication analysis and role-playing. The therapist identifies the primary problem area through the interpersonal inventory conducted early in treatment.

questions.stem: Select ALL evidence-based treatments that have RCT support for Borderline Personality Disorder (BPD):

options.text: Dialectical Behavior Therapy (DBT)
Mentalization-Based Therapy (MBT)
Transference-Focused Psychotherapy (TFP)
Schema Therapy
Systematic desensitization with reciprocal inhibition

questions.explanation: Four treatments have RCT support for BPD: DBT (Linehan) -- the largest evidence base; MBT (Bateman & Fonagy) -- focuses on mentalizing capacity; TFP (Kernberg) -- analyzes transference patterns and split object relations; and Schema Therapy (Young) -- targets early maladaptive schemas and schema modes. Systematic desensitization is an anxiety treatment based on reciprocal inhibition (Wolpe), not a BPD treatment.

questions.stem: Select ALL accurate statements about Mindfulness-Based Cognitive Therapy (MBCT):

options.text: It is primarily designed for relapse prevention in individuals with three or more prior depressive episodes
It integrates mindfulness meditation practices with elements of CBT
It is the first-line treatment for acute major depressive episodes of moderate severity
It reduces relapse rates by approximately 50% compared to treatment as usual
It teaches decentering -- observing thoughts as mental events rather than reality

questions.explanation: MBCT (Segal, Williams, & Teasdale) is designed for relapse prevention in recovered patients with recurrent depression (3+ episodes), NOT for treating acute depression. It integrates mindfulness practices (body scan, sitting meditation, 3-minute breathing space) with CBT elements. It reduces relapse by approximately 50% and teaches decentering/metacognitive awareness. MBCT is most effective for individuals whose prior episodes were NOT preceded by major life events, suggesting it targets autonomous, internally-triggered relapse.

questions.stem: Select ALL DBT skills that belong to the Interpersonal Effectiveness module:

options.text: DEAR MAN (Describe, Express, Assert, Reinforce, stay Mindful, Appear confident, Negotiate)
GIVE (be Gentle, act Interested, Validate, use Easy manner)
FAST (be Fair, no Apologies, Stick to values, be Truthful)
TIPP (Temperature, Intense exercise, Paced breathing, Progressive relaxation)
PLEASE (treat Physical illness, balanced Eating, avoid mood-Altering substances, balanced Sleep, get Exercise)

questions.explanation: The Interpersonal Effectiveness module includes three skill sets: DEAR MAN (for asking for what one needs), GIVE (for maintaining relationships), and FAST (for maintaining self-respect). TIPP is a Distress Tolerance crisis survival strategy, and PLEASE skills belong to the Emotion Regulation module (reducing vulnerability to negative emotions).

questions.stem: Match each depression treatment to the developer or research group MOST associated with it:
questions.explanation: Cognitive Therapy for Depression was developed by Aaron Beck, based on the cognitive triad (negative views of self, world, future). IPT was developed by Klerman and Weissman, focusing on four interpersonal problem areas. Behavioral Activation emerged from Jacobson's component analysis showing the behavioral component was as effective as full CBT. MBCT was developed by Segal, Williams, and Teasdale specifically for depression relapse prevention.

questions.stem: Match each BPD treatment to the key theoretical mechanism it emphasizes:

columns.text: Integrating split object relations via transference analysis
Modifying early maladaptive schemas and schema modes
Developing the capacity to understand behavior in terms of mental states
Dialectical balance of acceptance and change strategies for emotional dysregulation

questions.explanation: DBT balances acceptance and change strategies to address emotional dysregulation in BPD (biosocial theory). MBT focuses on developing mentalization capacity -- understanding behavior as driven by mental states. TFP analyzes transference patterns to integrate split positive and negative representations of self and others (object relations). Schema Therapy targets early maladaptive schemas and works with four BPD schema modes (Detached Protector, Punitive Parent, Abandoned Child, Angry Child) to strengthen the Healthy Adult mode.

questions.stem: Select ALL treatment features that correctly describe each approach. Multiple selections per row are expected:

columns.text: Primarily for relapse prevention, not acute treatment

questions.explanation: Beck's CBT uses homework (thought records, behavioral experiments), directly targets cognitive distortions, and is time-limited (12-20 sessions). BA uses homework (activity scheduling, monitoring) and is time-limited, but does NOT directly target cognitive distortions -- it focuses on increasing response-contingent positive reinforcement. IPT is time-limited (12-16 sessions) but does NOT use homework in the CBT sense and does NOT directly target cognitions. MBCT is primarily for relapse prevention in remitted patients with 3+ episodes, not for acute depression treatment.

questions.stem: For each eating disorder, select ALL treatments with strong evidence. Multiple selections per row are expected:
questions.explanation: Bulimia nervosa has the most treatment options: CBT-E (first-line), IPT (equally effective long-term), and fluoxetine 60 mg (FDA-approved). Binge eating disorder responds to CBT-E (and lisdexamfetamine, not listed). Adolescent anorexia nervosa is best treated with FBT/Maudsley (first-line). Adult anorexia nervosa can be treated with CBT-E adapted for underweight patients, though no single therapy has demonstrated clear superiority. IPT is NOT a first-line treatment for anorexia, and fluoxetine is FDA-approved only for bulimia, not anorexia.

questions.stem: Linehan's biosocial theory proposes that BPD results from the transaction between a biological vulnerability to {{blank1}} and a developmental history of growing up in an {{blank2}}. The fundamental dialectic in DBT is between {{blank3}}. In individual therapy, diary cards are reviewed to set the agenda according to the {{blank4}}.

options.text: emotional dysregulation
cognitive rigidity
attachment avoidance
dissociative proneness
invalidating environment
enmeshed family system
authoritarian household
neglectful attachment context
acceptance and change
insight and behavior modification
conscious and unconscious processes
individual and systemic factors
treatment target hierarchy (life-threatening > therapy-interfering > quality-of-life > skills)
client's stated preferences for session content
therapist's clinical judgment about the most urgent concern
skills module currently being covered in the group

questions.explanation: DBT's biosocial theory posits that BPD develops from the transaction between biological emotional dysregulation (high sensitivity, intense reactions, slow return to baseline) and an invalidating environment (one that dismisses, punishes, or responds erratically to emotional expression). The fundamental dialectic balances acceptance and change. Diary cards tracking emotions, urges, behaviors, and skills are reviewed to set the individual session agenda according to the treatment target hierarchy.

questions.stem: In Beck's cognitive model, three levels of cognition are targeted: {{blank1}} are the most accessible and situation-specific, {{blank2}} are conditional rules like 'If I'm not perfect, I'm a failure,' and {{blank3}} are deep unconditional beliefs like 'I am worthless.' CBT treatment progresses from {{blank4}}.

options.text: automatic thoughts
core beliefs
intermediate beliefs
cognitive schemas
intermediate beliefs
automatic thoughts
core beliefs
metacognitions
core beliefs/schemas
intermediate beliefs
automatic thoughts
cognitive distortions
surface-level automatic thoughts in early sessions to deeper schema-level work in later sessions
core beliefs first so that automatic thoughts naturally resolve
intermediate beliefs because they bridge surface and deep cognitions
behavioral experiments before addressing any cognitive content

questions.explanation: Beck distinguished three levels of cognition: (1) automatic thoughts -- spontaneous, situation-specific, closest to conscious awareness; (2) intermediate beliefs -- conditional rules, attitudes, and assumptions (e.g., 'If...then'); and (3) core beliefs/schemas -- deep, unconditional, pervasive beliefs about self, others, and the world. CBT progresses from addressing surface-level automatic thoughts in early sessions (sessions 1-4) to intermediate beliefs in middle sessions (5-12) to core beliefs/schemas in later sessions (13-20).

questions.stem: A 32-year-old woman presents with chronic suicidality, self-cutting during emotional crises, chaotic relationships characterized by rapid idealization and devaluation, and severe difficulty tolerating distress. She reports growing up in a home where her parents dismissed her emotions, telling her she was 'overreacting' and punishing displays of sadness or anger.

options.text: Biological vulnerability to emotional dysregulation (high sensitivity, intense reactions, slow return to baseline)
Invalidating developmental environment that dismissed and punished emotional expression
Insecure avoidant attachment leading to suppression of all emotional experience
Learned helplessness from repeated uncontrollable aversive experiences
Linehan's biosocial theory of BPD
Beck's cognitive theory of personality disorders
Bowlby's attachment theory of psychopathology
Individual therapy addressing the life-threatening behavior hierarchy, plus skills training group
Phone coaching for skills generalization and consultation team for therapist support
Twice-weekly transference-focused psychotherapy analyzing split object relations
Imagery rescripting of early maladaptive schema-related childhood memories

questions.explanation: This presentation exemplifies Linehan's biosocial theory: biological emotional dysregulation + invalidating environment = BPD features. The parental dismissal and punishment of emotions is the hallmark invalidating environment. Standard DBT addresses this through four modes: individual therapy (using the treatment hierarchy with life-threatening behaviors first), skills training group, phone coaching for generalization, and consultation team. TFP (transference analysis of split object relations) and Schema Therapy (imagery rescripting) are also evidence-based for BPD but represent different theoretical frameworks.

questions.stem: A 45-year-old man with recurrent major depression has had five previous episodes. He is currently in remission on maintenance antidepressant medication. His therapist observes that minor mood dips quickly trigger a cascade of ruminative negative thinking that has preceded each relapse.

options.text: High cognitive reactivity: automatic activation of negative thinking patterns by minor mood fluctuations
History of three or more depressive episodes increasing autonomous relapse vulnerability
Persistent negative cognitive triad requiring direct cognitive restructuring of core schemas
Interpersonal deficits creating chronic social isolation that triggers depressive episodes
Cognitive reactivity and the 'depressive interlock' targeted by MBCT
Response-contingent reinforcement deficit targeted by Behavioral Activation
Interpersonal role transition difficulties targeted by IPT
Mindfulness meditation practices (body scan, sitting meditation, 3-minute breathing space)
Teaching decentering -- observing thoughts as mental events rather than reality
Daily thought records to identify and challenge automatic negative thoughts
Activity scheduling to increase engagement in pleasurable and mastery activities

questions.explanation: This remitted patient with 5+ prior episodes and high cognitive reactivity is an ideal candidate for MBCT. The target mechanism is cognitive reactivity -- the automatic link between low mood and negative thinking (the 'depressive interlock'). MBCT uses mindfulness practices and teaches decentering (metacognitive awareness) to prevent ruminative cascades from triggering relapse. Thought records and activity scheduling are CBT/BA techniques for acute depression, not MBCT relapse prevention strategies.

questions.stem: Highlight ALL accurate statements about evidence-based pharmacotherapy for mood and eating disorders.
questions.passage: Pharmacological interventions play important roles across mood and eating disorders. [For mild to moderate depression, CBT and pharmacotherapy are approximately equally effective, and psychotherapy alone is a reasonable first-line treatment]. Research also shows that [CBT has an enduring effect that persists after treatment ends, whereas pharmacotherapy benefits typically disappear when medication is discontinued]. In eating disorders, [fluoxetine at 60 mg is FDA-approved for bulimia nervosa and can reduce binge/purge frequency]. Furthermore, [SSRIs have been shown to reliably produce weight gain in acutely underweight anorexia nervosa patients]. For binge eating disorder, [lisdexamfetamine is the only stimulant FDA-approved for an eating disorder]. Additionally, [anorexia nervosa has the highest mortality rate of any psychiatric disorder, making medical monitoring essential across all treatment approaches].

highlightableSegments.text: For mild to moderate depression, CBT and pharmacotherapy are approximately equally effective, and psychotherapy alone is a reasonable first-line treatment
CBT has an enduring effect that persists after treatment ends, whereas pharmacotherapy benefits typically disappear when medication is discontinued
fluoxetine at 60 mg is FDA-approved for bulimia nervosa and can reduce binge/purge frequency
SSRIs have been shown to reliably produce weight gain in acutely underweight anorexia nervosa patients
lisdexamfetamine is the only stimulant FDA-approved for an eating disorder
anorexia nervosa has the highest mortality rate of any psychiatric disorder, making medical monitoring essential across all treatment approaches

questions.explanation: CBT and medication are approximately equally effective for mild-moderate depression, and CBT has enduring effects post-treatment. Fluoxetine 60 mg is FDA-approved for bulimia. Lisdexamfetamine is FDA-approved for binge eating disorder. Anorexia has the highest mortality rate of any psychiatric disorder. However, the claim that SSRIs produce weight gain in underweight AN patients is FALSE -- no medication has been shown to reliably produce weight gain in acutely underweight anorexia nervosa patients.

questions.stem: Highlight ALL accurate descriptions of Schema Therapy for Borderline Personality Disorder.
questions.passage: Schema Therapy (Young et al., 2003) offers a comprehensive approach to BPD. [Schema Therapy identifies and modifies early maladaptive schemas (EMS), which are broad, pervasive themes regarding oneself and relationships that develop during childhood]. For BPD specifically, [schema therapy focuses on four maladaptive schema modes: the Detached Protector, the Punitive Parent, the Abandoned/Abused Child, and the Angry Child]. Treatment aims to [weaken pathological modes and strengthen the Healthy Adult mode through cognitive, experiential, behavioral, and relational strategies]. Experiential techniques include [empty chair work and imagery rescripting to rework early schema-related memories]. The therapeutic relationship in Schema Therapy [maintains strict abstinence from any emotional engagement beyond technical interventions to avoid reinforcing pathological schemas]. Schema Therapy has [demonstrated RCT support for BPD, alongside DBT, MBT, and TFP].

highlightableSegments.text: Schema Therapy identifies and modifies early maladaptive schemas (EMS), which are broad, pervasive themes regarding oneself and relationships that develop during childhood
schema therapy focuses on four maladaptive schema modes: the Detached Protector, the Punitive Parent, the Abandoned/Abused Child, and the Angry Child
weaken pathological modes and strengthen the Healthy Adult mode through cognitive, experiential, behavioral, and relational strategies
empty chair work and imagery rescripting to rework early schema-related memories
maintains strict abstinence from any emotional engagement beyond technical interventions to avoid reinforcing pathological schemas
demonstrated RCT support for BPD, alongside DBT, MBT, and TFP

questions.explanation: Schema Therapy uses EMS as the core construct, identifies four BPD schema modes, aims to strengthen the Healthy Adult mode, and uses experiential techniques like empty chair and imagery rescripting. It has RCT support for BPD. However, Schema Therapy does NOT maintain strict emotional abstinence -- the therapeutic relationship is actually used as a vehicle for 'limited reparenting,' where the therapist provides warmth and appropriate emotional engagement to help meet the client's unmet emotional needs from childhood.

questions.stem: Arrange the three phases of Beck's CBT for depression in the correct sequential order, from early to late treatment:

items.text: Establishing the therapeutic relationship, psychoeducation about the cognitive model, activity monitoring, and identifying automatic thoughts
Cognitive restructuring using thought records, behavioral experiments, and challenging intermediate beliefs (rules and attitudes)
Identifying and modifying core beliefs/schemas, relapse prevention planning, and spacing of sessions

questions.explanation: Beck's CBT for depression follows three phases: Early sessions (1-4) focus on relationship building, psychoeducation about the cognitive model, activity monitoring/scheduling, and identifying automatic thoughts. Middle sessions (5-12) involve cognitive restructuring with thought records, behavioral experiments, and challenging intermediate beliefs. Late sessions (13-20) address deeper core beliefs/schemas, consolidate gains, plan for relapse prevention, and space sessions to promote independence.

questions.stem: Arrange the three phases of Interpersonal Therapy (IPT) for depression in their correct sequential order:

items.text: Initial phase: Assessment, diagnosis, interpersonal inventory, assignment of the 'sick role,' and identification of the primary problem area
Middle phase: Focused work on the identified problem area using IPT strategies (communication analysis, role-playing)
Termination phase: Review of progress, consolidation of gains, and planning for the future

questions.explanation: IPT proceeds in three phases: (1) Initial phase (sessions 1-3) includes assessment, diagnosis, the interpersonal inventory (detailed review of significant relationships), assigning the 'sick role,' and identifying the primary problem area. (2) Middle phase (sessions 4-13) involves focused work on the identified problem area. (3) Termination phase (sessions 14-16) reviews progress, consolidates gains, and plans for the future. IPT is time-limited at 12-16 sessions.

questions.stem: A clinical trial compares CBT, Behavioral Activation (BA), and antidepressant medication for acute major depression, measuring Beck Depression Inventory (BDI) scores at baseline, mid-treatment (week 8), end of treatment (week 16), and 1-year follow-up (after all treatments discontinued).
questions.question: Which interpretation is BEST supported by these data trends?

options.text: Medication produces faster symptom reduction during treatment, but CBT and BA show better maintenance of gains after treatment discontinuation
CBT is clearly superior to both BA and medication at all time points
BA is inferior to both CBT and medication, suggesting behavioral components alone are insufficient
All three treatments produce identical outcomes at every time point

questions.explanation: The data show that all three treatments produce similar end-of-treatment improvements (BDI ~ 9-10). Medication produces slightly faster improvement at week 8 (BDI 16 vs. 19-20). However, at 1-year follow-up after treatment discontinuation, the medication group shows substantial relapse (BDI 22), while CBT and BA maintain gains (BDI 12-13). This pattern is consistent with research showing CBT has an enduring effect that persists after treatment ends, while pharmacotherapy benefits typically disappear when medication is discontinued.

questions.stem: A researcher tracks depressive relapse rates over 2 years for patients with recurrent depression (3+ prior episodes) randomized to MBCT plus treatment-as-usual (TAU) versus TAU alone, after recovery from their most recent episode.
questions.question: Which conclusion is BEST supported by this data pattern?

options.text: MBCT eliminates depressive relapse entirely in patients with recurrent depression
MBCT reduces the relapse rate by approximately 50% compared to TAU alone in patients with three or more prior episodes
TAU alone is sufficient for preventing relapse, and MBCT adds minimal incremental benefit
Both groups show equivalent relapse rates, supporting the Dodo bird verdict

questions.explanation: At 24 months, 32% of the MBCT group relapsed versus 64% of the TAU group -- a reduction of approximately 50%. This is consistent with research showing MBCT reduces relapse rates by about 50% for individuals with three or more prior depressive episodes. MBCT does not eliminate relapse entirely but substantially reduces the risk by teaching decentering and metacognitive awareness to interrupt the cognitive reactivity that triggers autonomous relapse.

questions.stem: Categorize each DBT skill or technique into the correct skills module:

items.text: Observing, describing, and participating with non-judgmental awareness
Radical acceptance of painful reality without trying to change it
Opposite action (acting counter to the emotion's urge when the emotion doesn't fit the facts)
TIPP skills (Temperature, Intense exercise, Paced breathing, Progressive relaxation)
PLEASE skills (Physical health, Eating, mood-Altering substances, Sleep, Exercise)
'What' skills and 'How' skills (observe, describe, participate; non-judgmentally, one-mindfully, effectively)

questions.explanation: Mindfulness includes observing/describing/participating (the 'what' skills) and doing so non-judgmentally, one-mindfully, and effectively (the 'how' skills). Distress Tolerance includes radical acceptance and crisis survival strategies like TIPP. Emotion Regulation includes opposite action (acting counter to unjustified emotions) and PLEASE skills (reducing vulnerability to negative emotions through self-care).

questions.stem: Categorize each treatment feature or intervention into the correct eating disorder treatment approach:

items.text: Self-monitoring of eating, purging, and associated thoughts in real time
Parents take full charge of refeeding; the eating disorder is externalized as separate from the adolescent
Focuses on grief, role disputes, role transitions, and interpersonal deficits without directly targeting eating behaviors
Challenging overvaluation of shape, weight, and eating control as core psychopathology
Phase 1 involves weight restoration directed by parents; Phase 2 returns control to the adolescent
Eating symptoms improve indirectly as interpersonal functioning improves

questions.explanation: CBT-E uses real-time self-monitoring and challenges the overvaluation of shape/weight/eating as core pathology (transdiagnostic model). FBT/Maudsley empowers parents for refeeding (Phase 1), externalizes the illness, and gradually returns control (Phase 2). IPT for bulimia works on interpersonal problem areas without directly targeting eating behaviors, and symptoms improve as interpersonal functioning improves. IPT is as effective as CBT long-term for bulimia, though CBT produces faster improvement.
